market_power_map.mechanism_of_power: PRICING AND PROGRAM CONTROL: Hyperscalers exercise power through: (1) UNILATERAL INFRASTRUCTURE PRICING - set list rates that determine 89.6% of customer spend with no MSP negotiation, can reduce prices forcing MSP revenue decline even if management fees constant, (2) PARTNER CREDIT CONTROL - determine partner rebates/credits (5-15%) that constitute MSP infrastructure margin, can modify quarterly/annually with zero advance notice, no disclosed long-term guarantees, (3) DISINTERMEDIATION AUTHORITY - offer competing managed services (AWS Managed Services, Azure Managed Services) directly to MSP customers, can directly solicit MSP customers to go direct with incentives, (4) RELATIONSHIP VISIBILITY - have direct visibility into customer workloads and consumption enabling competitive intelligence and targeting, (5) PARTNERSHIP TERMINATION - can terminate reseller agreements with minimal business impact to hyperscaler but existential impact to MSP. Power derives from: MSP existential dependency (100% of Public Cloud revenue requires hyperscaler access) vs hyperscaler indifference (MSPs represent <0.5% of hyperscaler revenue). EVIDENCE: Stage 2.5 documents 89.6% value capture, unilateral credit control, <0.5% revenue materiality asymmetry.
market_power_map.who_loses_value: Managed Service Providers (MSPs) including Rackspace lose value through: (1) MARGIN COMPRESSION - if hyperscalers reduce partner credits from 10% to 5%, MSP gross margin falls from 10.4% to 5.4%, potentially below breakeven after overhead allocation, (2) REVENUE DECLINE - hyperscaler price reductions compress MSP revenue when management fees structured as percentage of infrastructure spend, (3) CUSTOMER DISINTERMEDIATION - hyperscaler-direct managed services enable customers to eliminate MSP intermediation with minimal technical friction (1-3 months, only management layer changes per Stage 2.4), (4) COMPETITIVE DISADVANTAGE - hyperscalers subsidize direct managed services to capture customer relationships, undercutting MSP pricing while offering broader service portfolio. EVIDENCE: Stage 2.2 Public Cloud gross margin 10.4% reflects thin MSP capture, Stage 2.5 documents 20-30X profit asymmetry ($0.55-0.65 hyperscaler profit vs $0.02-0.03 MSP profit per dollar of customer spend).
market_power_map.touch_test_what_breaks: IF HYPERSCALER REDUCES PARTNER CREDITS 50% (from 10% to 5%): Rackspace Public Cloud ($1,683M, 61% of revenue) gross margin falls from 10.4% to 5.4%. At 5.4% gross margin, segment contributes ~$91M gross profit vs current $175M. Loss of $84M gross profit eliminates 20-25% of company gross profit. Public Cloud segment becomes loss-making after overhead allocation ($709M SG&A at 25.9% of revenue means Public Cloud must absorb $435M overhead, requiring minimum 25% gross margin to break even). Segment would need to: (1) Pass through cost increase to customers (triggers churn to hyperscaler-direct per Stage 2.4 LOW lock-in), or (2) Shrink to match reduced economics (revenue decline from $1,683M to ~$800M to maintain breakeven economics), or (3) Exit Public Cloud entirely (61% of revenue eliminated). SYSTEMIC BUSINESS FAILURE from single partner decision. EVIDENCE: Calculated from Stage 2.2 margin data and Stage 2.5 partner credit economics.
evidence_sources: Stage 2.5: Hyperscalers capture 89.6% of customer spend, Rackspace 10.4%
Stage 2.5: Partner credits/rebates (5-15%) constitute Rackspace infrastructure margin, terms 'non-disclosed' and 'controlled by AWS/Azure/Google'
Stage 2.5: Rackspace <0.5% of AWS revenue, <0.3% Azure, <0.2% Google Cloud vs Rackspace 61% dependent on hyperscalers
Stage 2.2: Public Cloud gross margin 10.4%
Stage 2.5: 'Hyperscalers can modify partner programs, reducing Rackspace's infrastructure margin'
Stage 2.4: Public Cloud 'LOW' technical lock-in, customers can switch to hyperscaler-direct with 1-3 months minimal friction
Calculated impact: 50% credit reduction = $84M gross profit loss, making Public Cloud unprofitable after overhead

market_power_map.mechanism_of_power: VENDOR LOCK-IN AND UNILATERAL PRICING: VMware exercises power through: (1) CAPTIVE CUSTOMER BASE - customers built VMware-dependent workloads that cannot migrate to alternatives without 20-30% failure rate and multi-year timeline, (2) UNILATERAL PRICE INCREASES - Broadcom raised VMware prices 200-300% in 2023-2024 with zero customer consultation or negotiation opportunity, customers presented with take-it-or-leave-it terms, (3) MIGRATION DIFFICULTY - VMware-specific configurations, operational knowledge, and application dependencies create years-long migration paths with high risk of customer production disruption, (4) ALTERNATIVE SUPPRESSION - lack of feature-comparable alternatives (OpenStack less mature, Hyper-V less enterprise adoption) preserves VMware dominance despite aggressive pricing, (5) BROADCOM STRATEGY - explicitly accepting 20-30% customer attrition while maximizing profit extraction from remaining 70-80%, demonstrating willingness to lose customers to maximize per-customer value. Power derives from: MSP captivity to customer base already on VMware platform vs VMware indifference to individual customer loss (<0.5% revenue each). EVIDENCE: Stage 2.5 documents 200-300% price increase, Stage 1.3 identifies VMware vendor lock-in as structural constraint.
market_power_map.who_loses_value: Managed Private Cloud providers including Rackspace lose value through: (1) FORCED COST ABSORPTION - cannot pass 200-300% VMware price increase to customers without triggering churn acceleration (customers would migrate to public cloud alternatives rather than accept 20-30% Private Cloud price increases), (2) MARGIN COMPRESSION - Private Cloud gross margin compressed from 38.6% to estimated 25-30% if VMware costs absorbed, destroying majority of segment profitability, (3) NO EXIT PATH - cannot migrate customer base off VMware without 20-30% customer loss during multi-year migration plus likely acceleration of remaining customers to public cloud (if customers must migrate anyway, many choose public cloud over alternative private cloud platform), (4) COMPETITIVE DISADVANTAGE - VMware price premium makes Private Cloud increasingly uneconomical vs public cloud alternatives, accelerating structural decline. EVIDENCE: Stage 2.2 documents Private Cloud gross margin 38.6%, Stage 2.5 calculates $100-210M value transfer from Rackspace to VMware from price shock.
market_power_map.touch_test_what_breaks: IF RACKSPACE ABSORBS FULL VMWARE PRICE INCREASE: Private Cloud ($1,055M, 39% of revenue) gross margin falls from 38.6% to 25-30%. Private Cloud operating income falls from estimated $315-420M (40-50% of total OI per Stage 2.4) to $105-160M, destroying $210-260M profit (50-60% of company operating income eliminated). Remaining business: $1,682M Public Cloud revenue with ~$67M OI (15-25% margin per Stage 2.4) + $105-160M Private Cloud OI = $172-227M total OI. With $709M SG&A overhead, company becomes loss-making or marginally profitable. IF RACKSPACE PASSES THROUGH COSTS: Private Cloud customer price increases 20-30% trigger churn acceleration from -13% YoY to estimated -25-30% YoY (customers evaluate public cloud alternatives, competitive Private Cloud providers). Revenue decline of $260-315M in year one. Combined with margin compression from remaining customers, Private Cloud becomes existentially threatened. Either absorption or pass-through leads to FINANCIAL DISTRESS. EVIDENCE: Calculated from Stage 2.4 profit concentration analysis and Stage 2.2 margin data.
evidence_sources: Stage 2.5: 'Broadcom acquired VMware (Nov 2023) and IMMEDIATELY raised prices 200-300%' documented market reality
Stage 2.2: 'Cannot migrate existing VMware customers to alternatives without multi-year migrations with 20-30% failure rate'
Stage 2.5: Estimated $100-210M value transfer from Rackspace to VMware from price increase
Stage 2.4: Private Cloud contributes 40-50% of total operating income despite being 39% of revenue
Stage 2.2: Private Cloud gross margin 38.6% under compression from VMware costs
Calculated impact: VMware cost absorption eliminates $210-260M operating profit, making company unprofitable

actors_with_power: FedRAMP Joint Authorization Board (US Federal Government)
market_power_map.mechanism_of_power: AUTHORIZATION CONTROL: Regulatory gatekeepers exercise power through: (1) LEGAL MARKET ACCESS - FedRAMP authorization legally required for federal government business (FISMA, OMB directives), UK sovereignty compliance required for UK government/regulated entities, without authorization revenue potential is ZERO, (2) REVOCATION AUTHORITY - can suspend/revoke authorization for compliance failures, security incidents, or failure to remediate findings with zero appeal period, immediate loss of market access, (3) REQUIREMENT EVOLUTION - periodically increase security/compliance requirements, forcing providers to invest additional capital or lose authorization, (4) CHANGE OF CONTROL REVIEW - foreign acquirer invalidates FedRAMP authorization per Stage 1.5, domestic acquirer triggers 12-18 month re-authorization, creates M&A constraint eliminating 60-70% of potential acquirer pool, (5) ENTITY-SPECIFIC AUTHORIZATION - FedRAMP tied to Rackspace Government Solutions entity, UK Sovereign tied to Rackspace Limited, cannot be transferred or consolidated, forces permanent operational fragmentation. Power derives from: Provider existential dependency on authorization for market access vs gatekeeper indifference to any individual provider (100 FedRAMP alternatives exist, providers are interchangeable). EVIDENCE: Stage 1.5 documents FedRAMP change of control constraints, Stage 2.5 identifies authorization as market access gate.
market_power_map.who_loses_value: Compliance-dependent providers including Rackspace lose value through: (1) MANDATORY COMPLIANCE COSTS - FedRAMP $2-5M+ annually, UK Sovereign $1-3M+ annually, cannot be avoided or negotiated, pure tax on business, (2) ARCHITECTURAL ISOLATION - Government and UK Sovereign require separated infrastructure preventing economies of scale, SG&A efficiency requires $4B+ revenue per Stage 2.6 but fragmentation prevents consolidation, (3) M&A CONSTRAINT - FedRAMP foreign buyer exclusion eliminates 60-70% of acquirer pool, domestic buyers face re-authorization risk with customer loss exposure, reduces exit optionality and enterprise value, (4) OPERATIONAL INEFFICIENCY - dedicated US-citizen security teams (Government), UK-resident-only personnel (UK Sovereign), jurisdictional fragmentation prevents workforce arbitrage and global consolidation, (5) STRANDED INVESTMENT RISK - if authorization lost or segment fails, isolated infrastructure investment ($10-20M FedRAMP, $5-15M UK Sovereign) has ZERO recovery value, cannot be repurposed. Providers capture operating profit ($70-145M Government, uncertain UK Sovereign) but only conditionally on maintaining authorization (fragile). EVIDENCE: Stage 1.5 documents authorization constraints, Stage 2.5 quantifies compliance costs and M&A restrictions.
market_power_map.touch_test_what_breaks: IF FEDRAMP AUTHORIZATION LOST (security incident, compliance failure, change of control): Government segment ($270-410M revenue, 10-15% of total) terminates over 3-6 months as federal agencies legally required to switch to alternative FedRAMP providers. Loss of $70-145M operating profit (15-25% of total OI per Stage 2.4). Isolated Government infrastructure (dedicated data centers, US-citizen workforce) becomes stranded cost - cannot repurpose for commercial operations per architectural separation requirement. $10-20M initial authorization investment plus 9 years annual compliance costs ($18-45M cumulative) become sunk loss. IF FOREIGN ACQUIRER: Authorization automatically invalidated, Government revenue terminates unless buyer accepts proxy board and government security representative eliminating economic control (unacceptable to most acquirers), Government segment likely excluded from transaction or sold separately to US-only buyer at distressed valuation. Change of control constraint eliminates European, Asian, Middle Eastern acquirers representing majority of global buyer pool. STRATEGIC CONSTRAINT limiting exit paths. EVIDENCE: Stage 1.5 foreign buyer exclusion rule, Stage 2.5 Government profit contribution, calculated stranded investment cost.
evidence_sources: Stage 1.5: 'FedRAMP authorization tied to Rackspace Government Solutions entity... Cannot transfer without 12-18 month re-authorization'
Stage 1.5: 'Change of control to foreign acquirer INVALIDATES FedRAMP authorization'
Stage 2.4: Government segment estimated $270-410M revenue, $70-145M operating profit
Stage 1.5: FedRAMP authorization cost $10-20M initial, estimated $2-5M annual compliance
Stage 2.5: Authorization loss triggers immediate revenue termination (federal agencies legally required to use authorized providers only)
Calculated impact: Authorization loss eliminates $70-145M profit, foreign acquirer constraint eliminates 60-70% of buyer pool

actors_with_power: Large Enterprise Private Cloud customers (estimated <200 accounts representing 15-25% of revenue)
market_power_map.mechanism_of_power: CONCENTRATION AND SWITCHING OPTIONALITY: Large enterprise customers exercise power through: (1) REVENUE CONCENTRATION - estimated 15-25% of revenue ($410-685M) concentrated in <200 large Private Cloud accounts, loss of top 10-20 customers would eliminate 10-15% of revenue while fixed costs remain, (2) STRATEGIC ALTERNATIVES - can choose to: migrate to public cloud (hyperscaler-direct or different MSP), migrate to competitive Private Cloud provider (IBM, CenturyLink, colocation + managed services), or build internal private cloud capability (hiring VMware expertise, acquiring infrastructure), (3) NEGOTIATING LEVERAGE - despite VERY HIGH switching costs ($2-10M, 12-24 months per Stage 2.4), large customers can threaten switch during renewal negotiations to extract pricing concessions, commitment reductions, or service improvements, (4) MONTH-TO-MONTH BILLING - despite multi-year relationships, Stage 2.4 identifies month-to-month billing as standard, customers can exit with 90-180 day notice (subject to early termination fees for committed spend but not absolute barrier), (5) INTERNAL CAPABILITY - large enterprises have IT teams capable of evaluating alternatives and executing migrations, unlike smaller customers dependent on MSP expertise. Power derives from: Customer concentration creating asymmetric impact (single large customer loss materially impacts MSP) vs customer ability to absorb switching costs (large IT budgets can justify $2-10M migration investment for ongoing cost savings or service improvements). EVIDENCE: Stage 2.4 documents Large Enterprise VERY HIGH lock-in but also concentration risk, Stage 2.4 estimates 5-8% annual churn demonstrating customers DO switch despite high costs.
market_power_map.who_loses_value: Private Cloud providers including Rackspace lose value through: (1) PRICE PRESSURE - large customers use competitive alternatives and switching threat to negotiate discounts (estimated 10-20% below list pricing for large committed spend), compressing margins from segment average, (2) SERVICE COST INFLATION - large customers demand premium support (dedicated account teams, custom SLAs, priority escalation) increasing cost to serve, margin compression from service intensity, (3) CHURN IMPACT - loss of top 10 customers estimated $150-250M revenue, creates immediate SG&A deleverage (overhead becomes 35-45% of remaining revenue vs 25.9% current per Stage 2.2), (4) COMPETITIVE VULNERABILITY - hyperscalers and competitive MSPs specifically target large accounts with aggressive acquisition offers (free migration, discounted first-year pricing, enhanced support), requires Rackspace defensive pricing concessions to retain, (5) PROFIT CONCENTRATION DEPENDENCY - Large Enterprise segment contributes estimated 30-40% of operating income, creates existential dependency on retaining large accounts (loss of top accounts threatens business viability). EVIDENCE: Stage 2.4 identifies profit concentration, Stage 2.2 documents SG&A deleveraging risk.
market_power_map.touch_test_what_breaks: IF TOP 10 LARGE ENTERPRISE CUSTOMERS DEFECT (estimated $150-250M revenue, 5-9% of total, representing 10-15% of segment profit): Immediate revenue loss while $709M SG&A fixed costs remain - SG&A becomes 29-31% of remaining revenue (vs 25.9% current), margin compression across all segments from overhead deleverage. Private Cloud revenue falls from $1,055M to $805-905M, accelerating segment decline from -13% YoY to -18-24% YoY, reinforcing perception of terminal decline. Large customer defections create NEGATIVE SIGNALING - other customers perceive Rackspace as 'losing customers' and proactively evaluate alternatives (self-fulfilling exodus prophecy). With Private Cloud contributing 40-50% of total operating income, loss of 10-15% of segment profit eliminates $30-60M company operating income. If large customer losses concentrated in government/compliance segments, may trigger authorization reviews (FedRAMP perception of provider stability). CASCADING IMPACT from customer concentration. EVIDENCE: Calculated from Stage 2.4 concentration estimates and Stage 2.2 SG&A overhead analysis.
evidence_sources: Stage 2.4: Top 10-15 customers across high-margin segments estimated 15-25% of revenue ($410-685M)
Stage 2.4: Large Enterprise VERY HIGH switching costs ($2-10M, 12-24 months) but 5-8% annual churn demonstrates customers DO switch
Stage 2.4: Month-to-month billing standard, customers can exit with 90-180 day notice
Stage 2.2: SG&A $709M (25.9% of revenue), would increase to 29-31% if top customers lost
Stage 2.4: Private Cloud estimated 40-50% of operating income contribution
INFERENCE: Large customer concentration creates negotiating leverage and churn impact asymmetry

actors_with_power: Mid-Market Public Cloud customers (estimated 1,000-3,000 accounts representing 30-40% of revenue)
market_power_map.mechanism_of_power: COMMODITIZATION AND EXIT OPTIONALITY: Mid-market customers exercise power through: (1) ZERO CONTRACTUAL LOCK-IN - Stage 2.4 documents month-to-month billing with 30-day termination notice and no early termination fees, can exit at will, (2) LOW SWITCHING COSTS - estimated $50K-500K total switching cost with 3-6 month timeline per Stage 2.4, economic barrier is low (6-12 months cost savings justifies switch), (3) ABUNDANT ALTERNATIVES - can choose: hyperscaler-direct (AWS/Azure/Google), competing MSPs (dozens of alternatives), multi-cloud management platforms, or internal cloud team build, (4) HYPERSCALER INCENTIVES - AWS/Azure/Google offer migration credits, free consulting, and discounts to win customers from MSPs, often fully offsetting switching costs making migration economically free, (5) PRICE SENSITIVITY - mid-market customers continuously evaluate costs and alternatives due to budget constraints, ANY price increase (even 5-10%) triggers competitive evaluation per Stage 2.4. Power derives from: Collective revenue materiality (30-40% of revenue) vs individual customer replaceability creating COMMODITIZATION - MSP cannot afford to lose segment but cannot differentiate to prevent attrition. EVIDENCE: Stage 2.4 documents LOW lock-in, Stage 2.2 Public Cloud 10.4% margin reflects commoditization and lack of differentiation.
market_power_map.who_loses_value: Public Cloud MSPs including Rackspace lose value through: (1) MARGIN COMPRESSION - commoditization drives margins to floor (10.4% gross margin, estimated 15-25% operating margin per Stage 2.4), cannot price above hyperscaler-direct cost + minimal management markup, (2) HIGH CHURN - estimated 15-25% annual churn per Stage 2.4 requires $250-420M annual new bookings just to offset attrition before any growth (with $1,683M Public Cloud revenue), (3) CUSTOMER ACQUISITION COST ESCALATION - competitive market requires aggressive customer acquisition spending (free migrations, discounted pricing, sales incentives), Stage 2.1 identifies 14% bookings growth but -7% revenue decline indicating acquisition investment exceeding retention value, (4) DISINTERMEDIATION THREAT - hyperscalers actively solicit MSP customers to go direct, offering competing managed services at lower cost by eliminating reseller layer, MSP has no defense except further margin concession, (5) VALUE PROPOSITION EROSION - as hyperscalers improve direct managed services and customer cloud expertise increases, MSP value proposition diminishes (customers increasingly question 'why pay 10% markup for commoditized support?'). Segment is STRUCTURALLY PRESSURED - cannot differentiate, cannot lock in customers, cannot prevent hyperscaler disintermediation. EVIDENCE: Stage 2.2 margin data, Stage 2.4 churn estimates, Stage 2.1 bookings/revenue leakage analysis.
market_power_map.touch_test_what_breaks: IF MID-MARKET CHURN ACCELERATES FROM 15-25% TO 30-40% (due to hyperscaler competition, service quality degradation, or price pressure): Public Cloud revenue declines from $1,683M to $1,010-1,177M in year one (losing $506-673M revenue, 18-25% of total). With 14% bookings growth unable to offset current 21% net leakage per Stage 2.1, acceleration would create 30-35% net revenue decline annually. At this trajectory, Public Cloud declines to <$700M within 2 years. With $709M SG&A overhead requiring spread across all segments, loss of Public Cloud revenue creates SG&A ratio of 40-50% (vs 25.9% current), making business structurally unprofitable. Must either: (1) Exit Public Cloud entirely (eliminating 61% of revenue), (2) Dramatically cut SG&A by 40-50% ($280-355M cost reduction, likely requiring 50%+ headcount reduction), or (3) Accept bankruptcy trajectory. DEATH SPIRAL from mid-market customer power in commoditized market. EVIDENCE: Calculated from Stage 2.1 leakage analysis, Stage 2.4 churn estimates, Stage 2.2 overhead structure.
evidence_sources: Stage 2.4: Mid-Market LOW lock-in, 30-day termination, $50K-500K switching costs, 3-6 month timeline
Stage 2.4: Estimated 15-25% annual churn for Public Cloud mid-market
Stage 2.2: Public Cloud gross margin 10.4% reflects commoditization
Stage 2.1: 21% net revenue leakage (14% bookings growth - 7% revenue decline)
Stage 2.4: Hyperscalers offer incentives (migration credits, discounts) making customer acquisition competitive
INFERENCE: Mid-market customers have exit power through commoditization and low switching costs
Calculated impact: 30-40% churn acceleration creates 30-35% net revenue decline annually, death spiral
